user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_apply_params:
```c
static int
check_apply_params (void)
{
  if (tool_params.help)
  {
    show_help ();
    return -1;
  }
  else if (tool_params.version)
  {
    print_version ();
    return -1;
  }
  check_param_port ();
  check_apply_param__all_cpus ();
  check_apply_param__threads ();
  if (! check_apply_param__thread_per_conn ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  if (! check_param__epoll ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  if (! check_param__poll ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  check_param__empty_tiny_medium_large ();
  check_param__shared_single_unique ();
  if (! check_param__connections ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no controlling expressions that are invariant. Specifically:
- if (tool_params.help) and else if (tool_params.version): these test struct members (runtime data), not compile-time constants.
- if (! check_apply_param__thread_per_conn()), if (! check_param__epoll()), if (! check_param__poll()), and if (! check_param__connections()): each uses a function call result as the controlling expression, so they are not compile-time invariant.
- There are no loop constructs (for, while, do-while) with invariant controlling expressions; the code only contains straight-line function calls and conditional returns.
- Return statements return constant values, but returns are not controlling expressions for Rule 14.3.
Given all conditional tests depend on runtime values or function calls, none appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 (controlling expressions shall not be invariant). If any of the called functions or tested fields are in fact defined as compile-time constants/macros elsewhere, those definitions should be reviewed, but within this function the controlling expressions are not manifestly invariant.
